      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/bendybear-shellcode-blacktech/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Highly malleable, highly sophisticated and over 10,000 bytes of machine code. This is what Unit 42 researchers were met with during code analysis of this “bear” of a file. The code behavior and features strongly correlate with that of the WaterBear malware family, which has been active since as early as 2009. Analysis by <a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/19/l/waterbear-is-back-uses-api-hooking-to-evade-security-product-detection.html">Trend Micro </a>and <a href="https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/ja/2020/02/japan-security-analyst-conference-2020-1.html">TeamT5 </a>unveiled WaterBear as a multifaceted, stage-two implant, capable of file transfer, shell access, screen capture and much more. The malware is associated with the cyber espionage group <a href="https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3991160">BlackTech</a>, which many in the broader threat research community have assessed to have ties to the Chinese government, and is believed to be responsible for recent attacks against several East Asian government organizations. Due to the similarities with WaterBear, and the polymorphic nature of the code, Unit 42 named this novel Chinese shellcode “BendyBear.” It stands in a class of its own in terms of being one of the most sophisticated, well-engineered and difficult-to-detect samples of shellcode employed by an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT).</p>
<p>The BendyBear sample was determined to be x64 shellcode for a stage-zero implant whose sole function is to download a more robust implant from a command and control (C2) server. Shellcode, despite its name, is used to describe the small piece of code loaded onto the target immediately following exploitation, regardless of whether or not it actually spawns a command shell. At 10,000+ bytes, BendyBear is noticeably larger than most, and uses its size to implement advanced features and anti-analysis techniques, such as modified RC4 encryption, signature block verification, and polymorphic code.</p>
<p>The sample analyzed in this blog was identified by its connections to a malicious C2 domain published by <a href="https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3991160">Taiwan's Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau</a> in August 2020. It was discovered absent additional information regarding the exploit vector, potential victims or intended use.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers can be protected from the attacks outlined in this blog with the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> alongside <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/dns-security">DNS Security</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/web-security">URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> security subscriptions, and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_5lb2ldpzf0wc"></a>A New Class of Shellcode</h2>
<p>At a macro level, BendyBear is unique in that it:</p>
<ul>
<li>Transmits payloads in modified RC4-encrypted chunks. This hardens the encryption of the network communication, as a single RC4 key will not decrypt the entire payload.</li>
<li>Attempts to remain hidden from cybersecurity analysis by explicitly checking its environment for signs of debugging.</li>
<li>Leverages existing Windows registry key that is enabled by default in Windows 10 to store configuration data.</li>
<li>Clears the host’s DNS cache every time it attempts to connect to its C2 server, thereby requiring that the host resolve the current IP address for the malicious C2 domain each time.</li>
<li>Generates unique session keys for each connection to the C2 server.</li>
<li>Obscures its connection protocol by connecting to the C2 server over a common port (443), thereby blending in with normal SSL network traffic.</li>
<li>Employs polymorphic code, changing its runtime footprint during code execution to thwart memory analysis and evade signaturing.</li>
<li>Encrypts or decrypts function blocks (code blocks) during runtime, as needed, to evade detection.</li>
<li>Uses position independent code (PIC) to throw off static analysis tools.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the following sections, we provide an in-depth technical breakdown of each of these capabilities.</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_htzttzp7krgc"></a>Technical Details</h2>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_kym5vhjz1ccd"></a><strong>Shellcode Execution</strong></h4>
<p>The shellcode (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64CC899EC85F612270FCFB120A4C80D52D78E68B05CAF1014D2FE06522F1E2D0</span>) is considered to be a stager, or downloader, whose function is to download an implant from a C2 server. During execution, the code employs byte randomization to obscure its behavior. This is achieved by using the host’s current time as a seed for a pseudorandom number generator, and then performing additional operations against that output. The resulting values are used to overwrite blocks of previously executed code. This byte manipulation is the first anti-analysis technique observed in the code, as any attempt to dump the memory segment would result in illegitimate or incorrect operations. Figure 1 shows an example of the shellcode main entry point before and during runtime execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_116934" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116934" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116934" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-15.png" alt="The screenshot shows the orignal entry point on the left (before runtime execution) and the modified entry point on the right (during runtime execution), displaying the effects of byte manipulation. " width="900" height="255" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116934" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Modified shellcode runtime example.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Because shellcode lacks the ability to run on its own, a Windows loader is required to allocate an environment in memory for it to execute. At the time of analysis, no loader had been identified for this shellcode; Therefore, Unit 42 created a custom loader to study the code during its runtime execution. Since then, however, several older installers were discovered with embedded WaterBear shellcode based on attributes identified from this sample. More information on these loaders can be found in the Appendix section “<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x86 WaterBear Loaders</span>”.</p>
<p>The shellcode begins by locating the target’s Process Environment Block (PEB) to check if it’s currently being debugged. However, the code is written such that it pulls both the “BeingDebugged” and “BitField” values from the PEB, resulting in code logic that invalidates the debugger check. Because of this, the shellcode will always fail to recognize when a debugger is attached. This routine is performed 52 times in a while loop.</p>
<p>Next, the shellcode iterates through the PEB’s loader module list looking for the base address of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Kernel32.dll</span>. This is typical of shellcode, as the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Kernel32.dll</span> base address is necessary to resolve any dependency files required by the shellcode to run. With this address, the shellcode loads its dependency modules and resolves any necessary Windows Application Programming Interface (API) calls using standard shellcode API hashing. The following modules are loaded:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Advapi32.dll</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Kernel32.dll</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Msvcrt.dll</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">User32.dll</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ws2_32.dll</span></li>
</ul>
<p>With the shellcode initialization complete, it moves onto its main function. It begins by querying the target’s registry, at the following key:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Console\QuickEdit</span></li>
</ul>
<p>This registry key is used by the Windows command prompt to enable Quick Edit mode. Quick Edit mode allows copy and paste from the command prompt to the clipboard. By default, this key contains a REG_DWORD, a 32-bit number of either 1 for enabled or 0 for disabled. BendyBear reads this value, multiplies it by 1000 and performs the following calculation on the result:</p>
<p>If the result is less than 1,000 or greater than 3,300,000 the shellcode configuration (QuickEdit) is 4,000 (0xFA0) otherwise it is the result of the computed value.</p>
<p>Refer to the highlighted light blue value in Figure 2 Shellcode configuration.</p>
<p>This check is performed each and every time the shellcode is executed. One explanation for the use of this key is that the value is written to by the shellcode loader (to a value other than 0 or 1) and it’s used by the shellcode to obtain configuration settings.</p>
<p>It then decrypts its internal configuration structure, which is 1,152 bytes. An example is shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_116936" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116936" style="width: 866px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116936" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-16.png" alt="BendyBear decrypts its internal configuration structure, which is 1,152 bytes, as shown in the example above. Highlights in various colors help break down the configuration structure: neon green are the keys used for XORing values throughout the shellcode, light blue are the bytes computed from the host's Quick Edit Registry key, orange are the four bytes that represent the shellcode version, pink are the 17 bytes that make up the C2 domain, magenta are the two bytes that make up the target C2 port, light yellow are the resolved function pointers used by the shellcode, dark cyan are the 112 bytes that make up the function pointer sizes used to encrypt or decrypt function blocks, and dark red are the 289 bytes that make up the resolved Windows API functions used by the shellcode. " width="866" height="1600" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116936" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Shellcode configuration structure.</figcaption></figure>
<p>A breakdown of the configuration structure shown in Figure 2 is below (from top to bottom):</p>
<ul>
<li>Highlighted in neon green are the two, 16-byte keys used for XORing values throughout the shellcode.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7D 38 BA FD E1 C8 D2 DF B6 EE 33 F9 14 BF 52 96 </span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">71 17 DF E4 AE 3B A9 F2 D5 3D 75 CC D3 0D 57 72</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in light blue are the two bytes computed from the host’s Quick Edit Registry key.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">E8 03</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in orange are the four bytes that represent the shellcode version.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">30 2E 32 34 (0.24)</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in pink are the 17 bytes that make up the C2 domain. Bitwise NOT (unsigned byte) to decode the values including the NULL.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">88 98 CE D1 96 91 94 9A 8C 93 96 89 9A D1 9C 90 92</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in dark green are the 103 bytes that are used for pattern elimination. XOR with 0xFF to NULL values.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF...</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in magenta are the two bytes that make up the target C2 port.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">BB 01</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in light yellow are the resolved function pointers used by the shellcode.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">92 13 73 33 37 02</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in dark cyan are the 112 bytes that make up the function pointer sizes used to encrypt or decrypt function blocks.<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">EE 01</span></li>
<li>Highlighted in dark red are the 289 bytes that make up the resolved Windows API functions used by the shellcode<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">A0 2E 52 CC FC 7F 00 00...</span></li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_h3rc26s91qz9"></a>Network Communications</h2>
<figure id="attachment_116938" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116938" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116938" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-17.png" alt="Stager communication flow: Stager generates request packet, C2 server calculates pre-session key and challenge response, C2 server returns encrypted chunk payload, stager verifies challenge response and decrypts payload and executes in-memory. " width="900" height="404" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116938" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Stager communication flow.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Before communicating with the C2 server, the shellcode flushes the host’s DNS cache by performing the following:</p>
<ol>
<li>Loads module <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dnsapi.dll</span></li>
<li>Calls API <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DnsFlushResolverCache</span></li>
</ol>
<p>When this API is called, all domains resolved are cleared from the host’s DNS cache, not just the target C2 server. This forces the host to resolve the current IP associated with the C2 domain, ensuring that communication continues as network infrastructure becomes compromised or unavailable. It also implies the developers own the domain and can update the IP.</p>
<p>The stager begins by computing 10 bytes of data to send to the C2 server. These 10 bytes make up a challenge request packet. The stager sends the challenge request to the C2 and waits for a challenge response. When received and properly decrypted, the stager checks for magic values or signature bytes at specific offsets. If this check fails, the network connection is aborted. This check ensures trusted communication with the intended C2 server and initiates the download of the payload.</p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_qfgf2i8zo8dv"></a>I. <strong>Stager Generates Challenge Request Packet</strong></h4>
<p>The stager computes a 10-byte challenge request containing information for the C2, to include the size of the data (being the session keys) to be received next. The challenge request and session keys are sent to the C2 simultaneously. Example request:</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">26BCFCCE738A211F3763</span></p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_ux471ma3zoz5"></a>II. <strong>C2 Server Decrypts Challenge Request Packet</strong></h4>
<p>The C2 decrypts the challenge request packet using the following steps:</p>
<p>1. First byte will be XORed with the second byte, second byte with third byte…until byte 10, followed by:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">A. Byte 7 is updated from the result of ( byte 7 XORed with byte 3 ).<br />
B. Byte 2 is updated from the result of ( byte 2 XORed with byte 0 ).<br />
C. Byte 8 is updated from the result of ( byte 8 XORed with byte 0 ).<br />
D. Byte 9 is updated from the result of ( byte 9 XORed with byte 5 ).</p>
<p>2. Final value is XORed with key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x3FDA5F9AD85D50C77E6A</span></p>
<p>The challenge request decrypts to the following (represented as hex bytes):</p>
<figure id="attachment_116940" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116940" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116940" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-18.png" alt="The C2 decrypts the challenge request packet, resulting in the following components: GetTickCount, Fixed Signature, GetTickCount, Fixed Value, GetTickCount, Data Size little Endian. " width="900" height="151" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116940" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Decrypted request challenge.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The last four bytes of the decrypted request packet inform the C2 server of the size of the expected network traffic to follow. As shown above, the value is 0x20, or 32 bytes. These 32 bytes make up the session keys used by the C2 server to encrypt a server challenge response and encrypt the payload.</p>
<p>Example of session keys received by the C2 server:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">Session key 1--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8C931D4F764B0661C26D77239EB454CA</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">Session key 2--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7A4DD0AA6C3F37CDBDAFA4CBD6B27697</span></p>
<p>The challenge request packet and session keys are computed for each beacon and therefore would always be unique.</p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_e2i6n8rpcdla"></a><strong>III. C2 Authenticates With the Stager</strong></h4>
<p>The C2 uses the session keys to build the RC4 state box and as an XOR key for encryption and decryption.</p>
<p><em>*It should be noted that the use of session key 2 is not yet fully understood, and it did not appear to be used to communicate with the stager.</em></p>
<p>1. The pre-session key is computed using session key 1 (first 16 bytes) as follows:<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Pre-Session Key = session key 1 XOR </span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0X6162636465666768696A6B6C6D6E6F00</span></p>
<p>2. Using the computed pre-session key from step 1, the C2 server builds the RC4 Key Scheduling Algorithm (KSA). It is computed as follows:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">a. Build the RC4 KSA using the following inputs to the below function:<br />
data = 16-byte key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x0C2F65194FF37B2D63D34635C7B205E4</span><br />
key = 16-byte computed pre-session key from step 1</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">   Example RC4 (modified) KSA routine:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> def rc4_KSA(data, key):<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      x = 0<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      box = range(258)<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      box[256] = 0<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      box[257] = 0<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      for i in range(256):<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      x = (x + box[i] + ord(key[i % len(key)])) % 256<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      box[i], box[x] = box[x], box[i]<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">      return box</span></p>
<p><em>*Note about the input parameter “data” for the KSA routine: It is the XOR result of the two 16-byte keys shown neon green in Figure 2. Shellcode Configuration Structure.</em></p>
<p>3. Construct 10-byte server challenge response header using the hex values shown in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_116942" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116942" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116942" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-19.png" alt="Server Command Challenge Header consists of: random value (shown in red), fixed signature (green), random value (light blue), command (dark blue), random value (gray), and header size little endian (orange). " width="900" height="260" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116942" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Server Command Challenge Header</figcaption></figure>
<p>4. Encrypt server challenge response header from step 3:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">a. XOR 10-byte server challenge with key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x33836E6B3FAA6AC464DA</span> and perform the following:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 80px;">i. Byte 7 is updated from the result of ( byte 7 XORed with byte 3 ).<br />
ii. Byte 2 is updated from the result of ( byte 2 XORed with byte 0 ).<br />
iii. Byte 8 is updated from the result of ( byte 8 XORed with byte 0 ).<br />
iv. Byte 9 is updated from the result of ( byte 9 XORed with byte 5 ).</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">b. Encrypted server challenge response header = result of 4(a)</p>
<p>5. Compute final authentication key:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">a. XOR the following values:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 80px;">i. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x0C2F65194FF37B2D63D34635C7B205E4</span><br />
ii. Value computed from step 1, i.e. Pre-Session Key</p>
<p><em>*The 16-byte value in 5.a.i is the same input parameter used in the KSA algorithm in step 2. The stager expects this key from the C2 otherwise the session is aborted.</em></p>
<p>The values generated in steps 4 and 5 make up the complete server challenge response. At this point, the C2 sends the server challenge response to the stager, completing the authentication process.</p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_5kl2u87wod5d"></a><strong>IV. C2 Encrypts and Transmits Payload</strong></h4>
<p>Next, the C2 prepares to send a command to the stager. BendyBear only supports one type of command: payload download.</p>
<p>1. Build a 10-byte command header using the hex values shown in Figure 6.</p>
<figure id="attachment_116944" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116944" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116944" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-20.png" alt="Updated Server Command Challenge Header consists of: random value (shown in red), fixed signature (yellow and green), random value (light blue), command (dark blue), random value (gray), and header size little endian (orange). " width="900" height="283" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116944" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Updated server command challenge header.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The only change to the header is the fixed signature value from 0x40 to 0x43.</p>
<p>2. Encrypt the command header from step 1:</p>
<p>The following is an example of a RC4 modified routine that can be used. The first argument, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">box</span>, would be the S-Box computed in step III.2 and the second argument, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">data</span>, would be the command header from step 1.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">def rc4_Mod_Crypt(box, data):</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    x = box[256]</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    y = box[257]</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    c = 0</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    out = []</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    for char in data:</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        x = (x + 1) % 256</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        y = (y + box[x]) % 256</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        box[x], box[y] = box[y], box[x]</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        z = ( (box[x] + box[y] )&amp;0xff ) % 256</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        al = rol( box[z],4,8 )</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        out.append( chr( ord( data[c] ) ^ al ) )</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        box[z] = al</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">        c+=1</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    box[256] = x</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    box[257] = y</span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">    return ''.join(out)</span></p>
<p>3. Obtain the size of the payload and encrypt that value using the same RC4 algorithm as in step 2. The size of the payload should be the total decrypted size of the payload.</p>
<p>4. Encrypt and send the payload to the stager in chunks:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">a. Read 4,086 bytes from the payload. This is the maximum chunk size that the stager will accept.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">b. Build a command header (step 1 above) and update the following fields:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 80px;">i. Header size = size of payload chunk.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 80px;">ii. Command = 1.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">c. Send the updated 10-byte command header to the stager.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">d. Send the encrypted payload chunk.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">e. Repeat steps a - d until payload is sent.</p>
<p>Figure 7 shows an example of one payload chunk that is sent to the stager.</p>
<figure id="attachment_116946" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116946" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116946" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-21.png" alt="Encrypted payload header and data from our investigation of BendyBear. Color code: Purple for Response Header 10 bytes; Light green for Decrypted Payload Size; Gray for Encrypted Payload chunk; and Light Blue for Command Header. " width="900" height="347" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116946" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Encrypted payload header and data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Upon receiving each chunk, the stager strips the command header and decrypts the payload chunk in memory.</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_6gnckt1wuwlg"></a>Payload In-Memory Loading</h2>
<p>Once the payload is fully decrypted, the stager performs some basic checks to ensure that the payload conforms to a Windows executable. It validates the DOS and PE header and that the payload is a DLL. It then direct-memory loads the payload and calls into its entry point (AddressOfEntryPoint). The direct memory load of the payload emulates that of the Windows PE loader – LoadLibrary. As a result, the PEB LDR_DATA_TABLE_ENTRY metadata structures are not created and the PEB for the process running the shellcode has no record of the DLL loading, which can be used to detect rogue modules running on your host. This is visible in WinDbg running the command !address within the process that loaded the shellcode. An example is shown in Figure 8.</p>
<figure id="attachment_117000" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-117000" style="width: 599px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-117000 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Screen-Shot-2021-02-05-at-6.41.06-PM.png" alt="The PEB for the process running the BendyBear shellcode has no record of the DLL loading, which can be used to detect rogue modules running on your host. This is visible in WinDbg running the command !address within the process that loaded the shellcode, as shown in the example here." width="599" height="99" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-117000" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Artifact of direct in-memory loaded DLL.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In-memory artifacts:</p>
<ul>
<li>Type is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MEM_PRIVATE</span>, meaning it is private to the process that loaded it. On Windows platforms, DLLs are typically loaded as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MEM_IMAGE</span> so that they can be shared between different processes to save memory space.</li>
<li>Protection is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE(RWX)</span>, which means the area is writable and executable with a memory area containing an MZ header. The MZ header is the in-memory loaded module.</li>
</ul>
<p>The output of the WinDbg <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!address</span> command shown in Figure 8 spots the anomalous entry. The memory address of module <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x7ff4c2450000</span> was the result of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">private memory</span> allocation, protection set to RWX and usage containing an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MZ</span> header.</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_qny2e5wj94w7"></a>x64 Shellcode Behaviors</h2>
<p>The following table describes the main behaviors of BendyBear.</p>
<table style="width: 101.553%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;"><strong>Behavior Artifact</strong></td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><strong>ATT&amp;CK IDs</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">Query Registry</p>
<p>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Console\QuickEdit</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1012/">T1012: Query Registry</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">Command and Control</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/002/">T1573.002: Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">Payload transfer from remote host</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105/">T1105: Ingress Tool Transfer</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">Payloads in modified RC4-encrypted chunks</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002/">T1027.002: Obfuscated Files or Information: Software Packing</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">~65 calls to Windows API kernel32!GetTickCountKernel32 prior to the shellcode connecting to the C2 server. Used to encrypt or decrypt function blocks.</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497/003/">T1497.003: Time Based Evasion</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">Dynamic DLL Importing and API Lookups</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106/">T1106 Native API</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 70.4663%;">52 iterations of the shellcode obtaining the process environment block (PEB) and checking for IsDebugger flag</td>
<td style="width: 34.456%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082/">T1082: System Information Discovery</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 104.922%;" colspan="2">Eight calls to msvcrt!time prior to connecting to the C2 server</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 104.922%;" colspan="2">Clearing host’s DNS cache via API DNSAPI!DnsFlushResolverCache</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 104.922%;" colspan="2">PEB _LDR_DATA_TABLE_ENTRY metadata structures are not created, and the PEB for the process running the shellcode has no record of the DLL loading.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 104.922%;" colspan="2">Loaded payload module (DLL) has a type of MEM_PRIVATE</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 12pt;"><sup><em>Table 1. x64 shellcode commands executed.</em></sup></span></p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_hnszmlfp7m8g"></a><strong>BendyBear vs. WaterBear</strong></h4>
<table style="width: 101.1%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;"><strong>Attributes</strong></td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><strong>WaterBear</strong></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><strong>BendyBear</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">File Type</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;">EXE/DLL</td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;">Shellcode</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Implant Type</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;">Stage-2</td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;">Stage-0</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Modified RC4</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116948" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-22.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116950" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-23.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Additional Encryption</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;">UNKNOWN</td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;">Extra XOR Computations</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">16-Byte XOR keys</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116952" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-24.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116954" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-25.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Authenticated C2 Communications</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116956" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-26.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116958" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-27.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Signature Verification Magic Bytes</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;">1F 40</p>
<p>1F 43</td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;">1F 40</p>
<p>1F 43</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Chunked Payloads</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116960" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-28.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116962" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-29.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Polymorphic Code</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116964" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-30.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116966" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-31.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">In-Memory Loading</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116968" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-32.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116970" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-33.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">PEB Debugger Check</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116972" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-34.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116974" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-35.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Pattern Elimination</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116976" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-36.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116978" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-37.png" alt="" width="30" height="31" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Encrypt/Decrypt Function Routines</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116980" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-38.png" alt="" width="30" height="26" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116982" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-39.png" alt="" width="30" height="26" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">API Hooking</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116984" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-40.png" alt="" width="30" height="26" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116986" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-41.png" alt="" width="30" height="30" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Process Hiding</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116988" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-42.png" alt="" width="30" height="26" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116990" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-43.png" alt="" width="30" height="30" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 29.5249%;">Network Traffic Filtering</td>
<td style="width: 17.1328%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116992" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-44.png" alt="" width="30" height="26" /></td>
<td style="width: 135.356%;"><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-116994" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-45.png" alt="" width="30" height="30" /></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 12pt;"><sup><em>Table 2. Comparison of BendyBear and WaterBear. </em></sup></span></p>
<p><strong>File Type</strong> – WaterBear is a standalone PE/EXE. BendyBear is a x64 Shellcode that requires loader or code injection.</p>
<p><strong>Implant Type </strong>– WaterBear is a stage-2 implant with many capabilities; BendyBear is a stage-0 downloader.</p>
<p><strong>Modified RC4 Encryption </strong>– Both WaterBear and BendyBear use a modified RC4, but implement them slightly differently. WaterBear uses a 256 RC4 state box with byte shifting and addition within the key scheduling algorithm. BendyBear uses a 258 RC4 state box and performs XOR within the key scheduling algorithm.</p>
<p><strong>Additional Encryption </strong>– While both use encryption as a way to conceal artifacts, BendyBear was found to contain additional XOR encryption steps.</p>
<p><strong>16-Byte XOR Key </strong>– Both use the same 16-byte XOR key to create the pre-session key: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x6162636465666768696A6B6C6D6E6f00</span></p>
<p><strong>Authenticated C2 Communications </strong>– Both send an initial 10-byte challenge request followed by 32-byte session keys.</p>
<p><strong>Signature Verification Magic Bytes </strong>– Both use the same matching magic byte verification values.</p>
<p><strong>Chunked Payload </strong>– Both expect the payloads to be sent in encrypted chunks.</p>
<p><strong>Polymorphic Code </strong>– Both employ code manipulation during runtime execution with random bytes.</p>
<p><strong>In-Memory Loading </strong>– Both support the in-memory loading of payloads.</p>
<p><strong>PEB Debugger Check </strong>– Both check to see if the code is being debugged.</p>
<p><strong>Pattern Elimination </strong>–Both re-encrypt any decrypted strings upon use.</p>
<p><strong>Encrypt/Decrypt Function Routines </strong>– Both WaterBear and BendyBear obfuscate runtime function addresses.</p>
<p><strong>API Hooking </strong>– Variants of WaterBear implement API hooking, while BendyBear does not.</p>
<p><strong>Process Hiding </strong>– Variants of WaterBear can hide processes via API hooking, while BendyBear does not support this capability.</p>
<p><strong>Network Traffic Filtering </strong>– Variants of WaterBear can filter or hide network traffic via API hooking, while BendyBear does not support this capability.</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_jypwnxxa4vh1"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>The BendyBear shellcode contains advanced features that are not typically found in shellcode. The use of anti-analysis techniques and signature block verification indicate that the developers care about stealth and detection-evasion. Additionally, the use of custom cryptographic routines and byte manipulations suggest a high level of technical sophistication.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers can be protected from the attacks outlined in this blog in the following ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>The C2 domain used in this shellcode has been categorized as malware in <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/dns-security">DNS Security</a>, <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/url-filtering/url-filtering-overview.html">URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a>, which are security subscriptions for <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a> can identify and block the shellcode during execution.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/technologies/app-id">App-ID,</a> the traffic classification system in Next-Generation Firewalls, is capable of identifying applications irrespective of port, protocol, encryption (SSH or SSL) or any other evasive tactic used by the application. This shellcode attempts to communicate over TCP port 443 with traffic that does not conform to proper SSL or any other known application. As a matter of best practice, we advise customers to block unknown outbound TCP traffic in their security policies.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_uodc8dg4l52f"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_5knp9eupotcf"></a><strong>Shellcode Samples</strong></h4>
<p>x64 - (version 0.24)<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64CC899EC85F612270FCFB120A4C80D52D78E68B05CAF1014D2FE06522F1E2D0 wg1.inkeslive[.]com</span></p>
<p>x86 - (version 0.1)<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">49901034216a16cfd05c613f438eccee4a7bf6079a7988b3e7094d9498379558 web2008.rutentw[.]com</span></p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_o7guvru5np20"></a><strong>x86 WaterBear Loaders</strong></h4>
<p>The following executables have been identified as loaders/injectors that contain older WaterBear x86 shellcode. The shellcode code is identical to the x86 sample 49901034216.... (version 0.1) listed above.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5d1414b47d88e95ae6612d3fc211c29b35cc5db4a8a992f5e27cff5203ebf44b<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9880ba4f93cade2f6bbb4cc8efdcf087e8ac51b5c209ee32ad8134eb87ef70e1<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">682122f34027e3f8025928d446989b02952449f5e5930c2670f8f789f41573ff<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2a09ec2d6edadd06e18c841e0ed794ba3eeb21818476f75ccc0e5d40e08eac80<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">76ef704d21fbaaceca8a131429ccfb9f5de3d8f43a160ddd281ffeafc391eb98</span></p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_hjrlv4duncv3"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3991160">Taiwan News </a>– Taiwan urges blocking 11 China-linked phishing domains.<br />
<a href="https://www.ithome.com.tw/news/139504">iThome News</a> – The Bureau of Investigation’s recent investigation of several cases of Taiwan Government agencies hacked.<br />
<a href="https://jsac.jpcert.or.jp/archive/2020/pdf/JSAC2020_2_ycy-aragorn_en.pdf">TeamT5</a> – Evil Hidden in Shellcode: The Evolution of malware DbgPrint.<br />
<a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/19/l/waterbear-is-back-uses-api-hooking-to-evade-security-product-detection.html">TrendMicro </a>– WaterBear Returns, Uses API Hooking to Evade Security.<br />
<a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/17/f/following-trail-blacktech-cyber-espionage-campaigns.html">TrendMicro </a>– The Trail of BlackTech’s Cyber Espionage Campaigns.<br />
<a href="https://medium.com/cycraft/taiwan-government-targeted-by-multiple-cyberattacks-in-april-2020-1980acde92b0">CryCraft Technology Corp</a> - Taiwan Government Targeted by Multiple Cyberattacks in April 2020 Part 1: Waterbear Malware<br />
<a href="https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2020/11/elf-plead.html">JPCERT/CC Eyes</a> - ELF_PLEAD - Linux Malware Used by BlackTech</p>
<h2><a id="post-116929-_6ovadee9r6bp"></a>Appendix</h2>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_531ysdr48i1v"></a><strong>Shellcode Proof of Concept</strong></h4>
<p>Mock C2 server serving request to stager and sending a payload (DLL) that displays a message box:</p>
<table style="width: 98.9829%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 100%;">python.exe U42ETHOS_C2.py -l 8080 -p c:\temp\DLLSample.dll</p>
<p>[+] Started U42ETHOS_C2.py ver 1.0.0 waiting for connection on TCP port 8080</p>
<p>[!] Using payload file c:\temp\DLLSample.dll</p>
<p>[!] Received new connection from: ('192.168.163.138', 49918)</p>
<p>[-] Received Encrypted challenge Request Packet--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">40da9a64bf3992d39db6</span></p>
<p>[-] Decrypted challenge Request packet--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">46401f8c032320000000</span></p>
<p>[+] Session key 1--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9816f78b57fff54efb5419202d81a729</span></p>
<p>[+] Session key 2--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6ec83a6e4d8bc4e28496cac865878574</span></p>
<p>[+] Computed PreSessionKey--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f97494ef32999226923e724c40efc829</span></p>
<p>[+] Challenge command--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a3601149a495d02598b7</span></p>
<p>[-] Challenge key is--&gt; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f55bf1f67d6ae90bf1ed3479875dcdcd</span></p>
<p>[+] Payload Size is 00920100</p>
<p>[!] Payload sent to stager. Check if executed</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 12pt;"><em><sup>Figure 9. Unit 42 mock C2 server.</sup> </em></span></p>
<figure id="attachment_116996" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116996" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116996" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-46.png" alt="Example stager in-memory loading test DLL for BendyBear. " width="900" height="367" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116996" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Example stager in-memory loading test DLL</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 9 is a Python mock C2 server that was created by Unit 42 to interact with the stager. It is configured to listen on TCP port 8080, and the payload is a test DLL that launches <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">calc.exe</span> and displays a message box (Hello, Implant). Figure 10 is a Windows 10 host running the shellcode in memory via a custom loader. The shellcode was configured to communicate with the mock C2 server.</p>
<h4><a id="post-116929-_knryjjv58o1r"></a><strong>Network Traffic for the Above Payload (truncated):</strong></h4>
<figure id="attachment_116998" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-116998" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-116998" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/word-image-47.png" alt="Figure 11. Network traffic capture example." width="900" height="1312" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-116998" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Network traffic capture example.</figcaption></figure>

                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/north-korean-threat-actors-lure-tech-job-seekers-as-fake-recruiters/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware</h4>
                  </a>

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider"  data-card-link="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/machine-learning-new-swiss-army-suite-tool/" data-video-cta-tracking="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning:card:video-modal:Read the article" data-video-title="Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning">

                              <figure>
                <img width="718" height="440" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Tutorial_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of machine learning detecting vulnerability scanning.                             </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/machine-learning-new-swiss-army-suite-tool/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/machine-learning/" title="Machine Learning" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning:Machine Learning">Machine Learning</a>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of Stately Taurus&#039; updated TTPs.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dll-sideloading/" title="DLL Sideloading" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:DLL Sideloading">DLL Sideloading</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/advanced-persistent-threat/" title="Advanced Persistent Threat" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:Advanced Persistent Threat">Advanced Persistent Threat</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/china/" title="China" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:China">China</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/" title="Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of malware such as WikiLoader. Red and blue digital data flowing from microchips on a circuit board, representing high-tech computing." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-protect-vpn-spoof-distributes-wikiloader/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bendybear-shellcode-blacktech:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/adem"   role="link" title="Autonomous Digital Experience Management" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management">Autonomous Digital Experience Management</a>
						</li>

              </a>
          </div>

            </div>

          </button>

              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">

                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>

                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
